hints.content:
###What the setup tells us

Eight kinds of flowers are being shipped “one after another”, which tells us we’re working with an **ordering setup**. There aren’t any grouping aspects to this task, so it’s not a mixed setup. A basic ordering diagram could look like this:

[[☃ image 1]]

###What do the rules tell us?

* **Rule 1:** The **Sunflowers** must be shipped earlier than the **Orchids**. We can show this relationship using a dash.

* **Rule 2:** The **Orchids** must be shipped earlier than the **Roses**, the **Violets**, and the **Zinnias**. We can again use dashes, but note that we *don’t* know the relationship between **Violets** and **Zinnias**, for example—we only know how three of the flowers relate to **Orchids** specifically.

* **Rule 3:** The **Zinnias** must be shipped earlier than the **Lilies**.

* **Rule 4:** The **Tulips** must be shipped earlier than both the **Lilies** and the **Mums**:

[[☃ image 2]]

Note that some students prefer to combine as they go along; others prefer to keep the rules separate and then combine in a new step. As you practice these types of ordering tasks, feel free to choose the method that’s more comfortable for you.

###What can we deduce?

If you *didn’t* combine as you go through the rules, it’s a good idea to do so now. We’ll combine rules that have an element in common, with the goal of creating a larger chain of elements. It doesn’t matter what order you combine in, but we like to start with the largest chain—in this case, the **O/R/V/Z** chain.

* From there, we can add the **S—O** chain, using **O** as the common element.
* We can add the **Z—L** chain, using **Z** as the common element.
* Finally, we can add the **T/L/M** group, using **L** as the common element:

[[☃ image 3]]

Before moving on to the questions, we can ask ourselves a few questions.

*Are all elements accounted for in the primary chain?*  

* Yes; the introductory paragraph mentions eight types of flowers, and all eight are represented in the primary chain.
* If this *weren’t* the case, we would want to be very careful to keep the missing element(s) in mind, as it/they could go *anywhere* in the order!

*Which flower(s) could be 1st?*  

* **Sunflowers* __*and*__ **Tulips** could be 1st!
* Be careful not to overlook **Tulips** just because it’s “farther to the right” in the diagram. The dashes show only relative order, but *not* distance. 
* In other words, **Tulips** could be as early as 1st, because no other flower is *stopping* **Tulips** from being 1st. 
* You can think of the dashes as being “stretchy”.
* So, any flower that *doesn’t* have a flower directly connected to the left of it can be 1st.

*Which flower(s) could be last?*

* There are four: **Roses**, **Violets**, **Lilies**, and **Mums**.
* Again, this is because none of these four flowers are *prevented* from being last.

***Remember:*** if two elements aren’t connected in a linear fashion in your chain, you *cannot* determine their relationship. Keep this in mind as you work through the questions!

options.alt: An ordering diagram and a list of elements. The list of elements runs vertically on the left, L M O R S T V Z. The ordering diagram is eight horizontal spots marked with bars and numbered 1 through 8.
A list of ordering rules in which the ordering relationships are noted with dashes. S dash O. O dash R and the same O dash V and the same O dash Z. Z dash L. T dash L and the same T dash M.
A chain of elements in which the ordering relationships are noted with dashes. S dash O dash V. The same O dash R. The same O dash Z. The same Z dash L. T dash the same L. The same T dash M.

options.passageText:
A flower shop owner is scheduling exactly eight shipments of flowers to be made on a given day. Each shipment consists of a different one of eight kinds of flowers—lilies, mums, orchids, roses, sunflowers, tulips, violets, or zinnias. The shipments will be made one after another, subject to the following conditions:

The sunflowers must be shipped earlier than the orchids.

The orchids must be shipped earlier than the roses, the violets, and the zinnias.

The zinnias must be shipped earlier than the lilies.

The tulips must be shipped earlier than both the lilies and the mums.

question.content:
Which one of the following CANNOT be one of the first four kinds of flowers shipped?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This can’t happen, so it’s the answer (note the word CANNOT in the question). Our main diagram shows that the **Lilies** must be shipped later than at least *four* other flowers (**Sunflowers**, **Orchids**, **Zinnias**, and **Tulips**), so the earliest the **Lilies** can be shipped is 5th.
This is possible, so it’s not the answer (note the word CANNOT in the question). The **Mums** could be one of the first four kinds of flowers shipped, for example: **TMSOZLVR**
This is possible, so it’s not the answer (note the word CANNOT in the question). The **Roses** could be one of the first four kinds of flowers shipped, for example: **SORVZTML**
This is possible, so it’s not the answer (note the word CANNOT in the question). The **Violets** could be one of the first four kinds of flowers shipped, for example: **SORVZTML**
This is possible, so it’s not the answer (note the word CANNOT in the question). The **Zinnias** could be one of the first four kinds of flowers shipped, for example: **SOZTLMRV**

hints.content:
* We can make a basic copy of our main diagram and place **Tulips** 6th.
* That means that **Lilies** and **Mums** must be 7th and 8th, though we don’t  know in what order (Rule 4).
* The **Sunflowers** are the only flowers that can be 1st, now that the question tells us that **Tulips** are 6th (remember that the **Tulips** are the only other flower that can be 1st in any scenario).
* The **Orchids** must be 2nd (since the other remaining flowers are all *after* **Orchids**):

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: An ordering diagram is eight horizontal spots marked with bars and numbered 1 through 8. In spot 1 is S. In spot 2 is O. In spot 6 is T. In spot 7 is L slash M. In spot 8 is L slash M.

question.content:
If the tulips are shipped sixth, which one of the following must be true?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This must be true. We’re told that the **Tulips** are 6th in this scenario, which means that the **Lilies** and the **Mums** must be 7th and 8th in some order (Rule 4). We can then deduce that only the **Sunflowers** can be 1st (since all of the other flower types must preceded by at least one different flower type), and the **Orchids** must be 2nd (Rule 2).
This could be true, but it doesn’t *have* to be true; for example, the **Zinnias** might be 5th: **SORVZTLM**
This could be true, but it doesn’t *have* to be true; for example, the **Roses** might be 3rd: **SORVZTLM**
This could be true, but it doesn’t *have* to be true; for example, the **Violets** could be 4th: **SORVZTLM**
This could be true, but it doesn’t *have* to be true; for example, the **Mums** could be 8th: **SORVZTLM**

hints.content:

* That means that the **Sunflowers** and the **T—M** chain must be 1st, 2nd, and 3rd. 


* That leaves the **Z—L** chain to be *after* the **Orchids** at some point. 
* So, the **Lilies** can’t be 5th or else there would be nowhere for the **Zinnias** to go:

[[☃ image 2]]

question.content:
If the orchids are shipped fourth, then any of the following could be true EXCEPT:


[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This is possible, so it’s wrong (note the word EXCEPT in the question). The **Tulips** could be 2nd, for example: **STMORVZL**
This is possible, so it’s wrong (note the word EXCEPT in the question). The **Sunflowers** could be 3rd, for example: **TMSORVZL**

This must be false, so it’s the answer (note the word EXCEPT in the question). In this scenario, we’re told that the **Orchids** are 4th. That means that the **Sunflowers**, **Tulips**, and **Mums** are the only flowers that could be 1st, 2nd, and 3rd. That leaves the **Z—L** chain to be *after* the **Orchids** at some point. So, the **Lilies** can’t be 5th or else there would be nowhere for the **Zinnias** to go.
This is possible, so it’s wrong (note the word EXCEPT in the question). The **Violets** could be 6th, for example: **STMORVZL**
This is possible, so it’s wrong (note the word EXCEPT in the question). The **Zinnias** could be 7th, for example: **STMORVZL**

question.content:
How many of the eight kinds of flowers are there that could be the kind that is shipped second?


[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This isn’t accurate. There are *four* flowers that could be shipped 2nd: **Sunflowers**, **Tulips**, **Mums**, and **Orchids**.

This is the answer. The four flowers that could be shipped 2nd are the **Sunflowers**, **Tulips**, **Mums**, and **Orchids**. The other four kinds of flowers are restricted in that at least *two* other flowers must be shipped earlier than they are.

This isn’t accurate. There are *four* flowers that could be shipped 2nd: **Sunflowers**, **Tulips**, **Mums**, and **Orchids**. The other four flowers each have at least *two* other kinds of flowers that are shipped earlier. For example, the **Zinnias** can’t be 2nd because the **Zinnias** are preceded by at least the **Sunflowers** *and* the **Orchids**.

This isn’t accurate. There are *four* flowers that could be shipped 2nd: **Sunflowers**, **Tulips**, **Mums**, and **Orchids**. The other four flowers each have at least *two* other kinds of flowers that are shipped earlier. For example, the **Violets** can’t be 2nd because the **Violets** are preceded by at least the **Sunflowers** *and* the **Orchids**.

This isn’t accurate. There are *four* flowers that could be shipped 2nd: **Sunflowers**, **Tulips**, **Mums**, and **Orchids**. The other four flowers each have at least *two* other kinds of flowers that are shipped earlier. For example, the **Roses** can’t be 2nd because the **Roses** are preceded by at least the **Sunflowers** *and* the **Orchids**.

* That means that the **Lilies** must be 8th (Rule 3).

If the zinnias are shipped seventh, which one of the following must be false?


[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This could be true (so it’s not the answer, since we’re looking for what must be false). The **Mums** could be 2nd in this scenario, for example: **TMSOVRZL**
This could be true (so it’s not the answer, since we’re looking for what must be false). The **Sunflowers** could be 3rd in this scenario, for example: **TMSOVRZL**

This can’t happen in this scenario, so it’s the answer (we’re asked to identify the choice that must be *false*). We’re told that the **Zinnias** are 7th, which means that the **Lilies** must be 8th (Rule 3). That means that the **T—M** relationship has to be earlier than the **Zinnias**. So, if the **Tulips** were 6th, there would be nowhere for the **Mums** to go.

hints.content:
* We can make a basic copy of our main diagram and place **Zinnias** 3rd.
* From this, we can deduce that the **Sunflowers** must be 1st and the **Orchids** 2nd (Rules 1 and 2).
* Since the question is focused on the 4th spot, let’s analyze that spot.
* The **Lilies** and the **Mums** *can’t* be 4th, since they’re each preceded by at least one flower that hasn’t been placed yet.
* So, the remaining flowers *could* be 4th: **Roses**, **Violets**, and **Tulips**:

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: An ordering diagram is eight horizontal spots marked with bars and numbered 1 through 8. In spot 1 is S. In spot 2 is O. In spot 3 is Z. In spot 4 is R slash V slash T. Below spot 4 is L with a slash through it and M with a slash through it.

question.content:
If the zinnias are shipped third, how many of the eight kinds of flowers are there that could be the kind that is shipped fourth?


[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This isn’t accurate. In this scenario, there are *three* kinds of flowers that could be shipped 4th—the **Roses**, the **Violets**, and the **Tulips**.

This is accurate. In this scenario, the three kinds of flowers that could be shipped 4th are the **Roses**, the **Violets**, and the **Tulips**. This  is because the **Sunflowers** and the **Orchids** must be 1st and 2nd, respectively (Rules 1 and 2), and the **Lilies** and **Mums** are preceded by at least the **Tulips**. So, the earliest the **Lilies** and **Mums** could be shipped in this case is 5th.
This isn’t accurate. In this scenario, there are *three* kinds of flowers that could be shipped 4th—the **Roses**, the **Violets**, and the **Tulips**.
This isn’t accurate. In this scenario, there are *three* kinds of flowers that could be shipped 4th—the **Roses**, the **Violets**, and the **Tulips**.
This isn’t accurate. In this scenario, there are *three* kinds of flowers that could be shipped 4th—the **Roses**, the **Violets**, and the **Tulips**.

hints.content:
###What the setup tells us

Four architects are assigned to four projects, one project per architect and one architect per project. That tells us that there’s a grouping task here. We’re *also* told that each project is completed “at a different time”, which is a strong indicator of an ordering task. So, we’re working with a **mixed setup**, which we can represent in a basic diagram that might look like this:


[[☃ image 1]]

###What do the rules tell us?

* **Rule 1:** Either **Fredericks** or **Lee** is assigned ***Z***. One way to represent this is with a rectangle that shows this grouping. It’s a good idea to make the rectangle match the orientation of the diagram in order to best discern where groupings can go.

* **Rule 2:** **Fredericks** is assigned ***W*** if **Guerrero** is not. Let’s be careful with this rule. It tells us that *if* **Guerrero** isn’t assigned ***W***, *then* **Fredericks** __is__ assigned ***W***. So, logically, if **Fredericks** *isn’t* assigned ***W***, then **Guerrero** __is__ assigned ***W***. What does that mean? One or the other *must* be assigned ***W***! Think of it as saying, “If I don’t buy groceries tonight, my roommate will.” There’s no way that both my roommate and I skip buying the groceries, because if I *don’t* buy it, they *will*. So if for some reason they don’t, that must mean that I buy them. So, either I or my roommate *will* buy groceries tonight. [In the groceries example, it’s possible that we both buy groceries, but here, it’s not possible for two architects to be assigned to the same project due to the constraints in the introductory paragraph.] This is a great deduction for us to make at this stage, and we can represent the rule with a rectangle similar to Rule 1’s rectangle.

* **Rule 3:** **Horowitz** is assigned ***Y*** if **Fredericks** is not assigned ***W***. Again, let’s rephrase this in an “if X then Y” structure, since students tend to have the easiest time with conditional logic that takes that form:  If **Fredericks** is not assigned ***W***, then **Horowitz** is assigned ***Y***. The contrapositive of this is that if **Horowitz** *isn’t* assigned to ***Y***, then **Fredericks** *is* assigned ***W***. From this, we can deduce—similar to what we deduced in Rule 2—that at least one or the other *must* happen; either **Horowitz** is assigned ***Y*** or **Fredericks** is assigned ***W*** or both. 

* **Rule 4:** **Fredericks**'s project is completed immediately before **Guerrero**'s. There are many ways to note this; we’ll use a horizontal rectangle.

* **Rule 5:** **Horowitz**'s project is completed last. We can build this directly into the diagram:

[[☃ image 2]]

It was important to take our time, particularly with the complex conditional logic rules. The time taken allowed us to get a head start on some of the deductions, and that’ll pay off when we get to the questions!

###What else can we deduce?

Rule 4 might jump out at you as being particularly interesting, given that we already placed **Horowitz** 4th, and there are only 4 spots. We have a great opportunity to build Multiple Scenarios, since only two things can happen around Rule 4—the **FG** pair can only fit two different ways into the diagram:

[[☃ image 3]]

Let’s analyze each scenario one at a time to determine what deductions we can make.

**Scenario 1:** **FG** is 1st/2nd.

* In this case, only **Lee** is left to occupy the 3rd spot. 
* Since either **Fredericks** or **Guerrero** is assigned to ***W*** (Rule 2), ***W*** can’t be 3rd or 4th.
* And, since either **Fredericks** or **Lee** is assigned to ***Z*** (Rule 1), ***Z*** can’t be 2nd or 4th.
* That means that the 4th spot has to be either ***X*** or ***Y*** (since we just determined that it can’t be ***W*** or ***Z***):

[[☃ image 4]]

**Scenario 2:** **FG** is 2nd/3rd.

* We can make similar deductions here! 
* Again, either ***X*** or ***Y*** is 4th, since ***W*** and ***Z*** both go with architects who *aren’t* **Horowitz**.
* ***W*** can’t be 1st or 4th (Rule 2), and
* ***Z*** can’t be 3rd or 4th (Rule 1):


[[☃ image 5]]

We no longer need the **FG** rule, since it’s built directly into our Scenarios. We can head to the questions armed with this main diagram:

[[☃ image 6]]

Since we took the time to build the Multiple Scenarios, the questions should be faster and easier to solve! If you’re new to Scenarios, you may want to try this setup again *without* using them, so that you can compare and get a feel for how they can improve your performance on Test Day.

options.passageText:
Each of four architects—Fredericks, Guerrero, Horowitz, Lee—is assigned a different one of four projects—W, X, Y, Z.  Each project is completed at a different time and the work assignments are governed by the following restrictions:

Either Fredericks or Lee is assigned Z.

Fredericks is assigned W if Guerrero is not.

Horowitz is assigned Y if Fredericks is not assigned W.

Fredericks's project is completed immediately before Guerrero's.

Horowitz's project is completed last.

question.content:
Which one of the following is a possible matching of architects with projects, in order from the first completed to the last completed?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This violates Rule 1 of the setup. ***Z*** can’t be assigned to anyone besides **Lee** or **Fredericks**.
choices.content: Fredericks: W, Guerrero: Z, Lee: X, Horowitz: Y

choices.clue: This violates Rule 4 of the setup. In this case, **Fredericks** doesn’t finish their project before **Guerrero**.
choices.content: Lee: Z, Guerrero: X, Fredericks: W, Horowitz: Y

choices.clue: This violates Rule 3 of the setup. In this case, **Fredericks** isn’t assigned ***W***, and yet **Horowitz** isn’t assigned ***Y***.
choices.content: Fredericks: Z, Guerrero: W, Lee: Y, Horowitz: X

choices.clue: This doesn’t violate any of the setup rules.
choices.content: Fredericks: X, Guerrero: W, Lee: Z, Horowitz: Y

choices.clue: This violates Rule 2 of the setup. ***W*** can’t be assigned to anyone besides **Guerrero** or **Fredericks**.
choices.content: Lee: W, Fredericks: Z, Guerrero: X, Horowitz: Y

question.content:
Which one of the following could be true?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This must be false. For one thing, **Guerrero** can never be 1st, since **Fredericks** is immediately before **Guerrero** (Rule 4).
choices.content: Guerrero's project is completed first and Lee's is completed second.

choices.clue: This must be false. For one thing, **Fredericks** can never be 3rd: **Fredericks** must be immediately before **Guerrero** (Rule 4), but **Guerrero** can’t be 4th when **Horowitz** is already 4th (Rule 5).
choices.content: Fredericks's project is completed third and Horowitz's is completed fourth.

choices.clue: This must be false. **Guerrero** can’t be 2nd unless **Fredericks** is 1st (Rule 4), but (C) places **Lee** 1st.
choices.content: Lee's project is completed first and Guerrero's is completed second.

choices.clue: This must be false. **Fredericks** must be immediately before **Guerrero** (Rule 4), but (D) puts **Fredericks** immediately before **Lee**.
choices.content: Fredericks's project is completed second and Lee's is completed third.

choices.clue:
This could be true, since it’s true in Scenario 2 of our initial setup. One possible situation could be:

**LFGH**  
***zwyx***
choices.content: Lee's project is completed first and Fredericks's is completed second.

hints.content:
* We can add the new condition that ***X*** is last (4th) to a new copy of our diagram. 
* ***X*** can be 4th in either scenario, so both of the scenarios apply.
* In both scenarios, since **Horowitz** is assigned to ***X***, **Fredericks** must be assigned to ***W*** (Rule 3’s logical equivalent). 
* In both scenarios, since **Fredericks** is assigned to ***W***, **Lee** must be assigned to ***Z*** (Rule 1).
* The remaining architect—**Guerrero**—gets assigned to ***Y***:

[[☃ image 1]]

If X is completed last, then which one of the following must be false?


[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue:
This could be true, so it’s not the answer (we’re asked for what must be *false*). ***W*** could be 2nd under this new condition, for example in Scenario 2:

**LFGH**  
***z__w__yx***

This is impossible (so it’s the answer, since we’re asked for what must be *false*). When ***X*** is last, ***W*** must be either 1st or 2nd, but never 3rd. That’s because **Horowitz** is always last (Rule 5), and if **Horowitz** isn’t assigned to ***Y***, then **Fredericks** must be assigned to ***W*** (Rule 3’s logical equivalent). And **Fredericks** can never be 3rd in either of our scenarios, since **Fredericks** needs to be directly before **Guerrero**.

This could be true, so it’s not the answer (we’re asked for what must be *false*). ***Y*** could be 2nd under this new condition, for example in Scenario 1:

**FGLH**  
***xwzy***

hints.content:
###What the setup tells us

Out of a total of six people, four will be nominated to run for office—since we’re choosing four out of six, this is a **grouping task***. We’re given more information about each office, which is that one person is nominated for ***mayor***, one for ***treasurer***, and two for ***councillor***. There’s no ordering task to work with, so this is a classic **grouping setup**. It can be helpful to create an Out column also; if we know who’s out, then we know who’s in. Your main diagram could look like this:

[[☃ image 1]]

###What do the rules tell us?

* **Rule 1:** If **Frost** is one of the nominees, **Grant** cannot be one of the nominees. This is a conditional logic rule, and it also indicates that if **Grant** is one of the nominees, then **Frost** is *not* one of the nominees (in other words, out).

* **Rule 2:** If **Hu** is a nominee for ***councillor***, **Jensen** must be the nominee for ***mayor***. This is another conditional logic rule, and it’s a good idea to note the logical equivalent: if **Jensen** *isn’t* the nominee for ***mayor***, then **Hu** *isn’t* a nominee for ***councillor***. 

* **Rule 3:** The nominee for ***treasurer*** must be either **Frost** or **Hu**. We can build this directly into our diagram.

* **Rule 4:** **Kuno** cannot be a nominee for ***councillor***. We can also build this directly into the diagram:

[[☃ image 2]]

###What can we deduce?

* From Rule 1, we can deduce that **Frost** and **Grant** *can’t* both be nominated. 
* That means that we can reserve an “Out” spot for either **Frost** or **Grant**.
* Be careful here! They *could* both be out; they just can’t both be in (nominated).

There isn’t much more that we can deduce. You could build Multiple Scenarios around **Hu* being ***councillor***, not ***councillor***, and *out*, but it isn’t necessary in this setup. Let’s move to the questions with this main diagram:

[[☃ image 3]]

Below that is the Treasurer row with one spot. Below that is the Councillor row marked with two spots. To the right is an Out row marked with two spots.

A grouping diagram and some rules. The grouping diagram consists of three rows on the left side and one row on the right side. The left side rows are the Mayor row with one spot marked with a horizontal bar. Below that is the Treasurer row with one spot. In the spot is F slash H. Below that is the Councillor row marked with two spots. To the right of the Councillor spot is K with a slash through it. To the right is an Out row marked with two spots.

All of the rules are conditional logic rules. F in right-arrow G out. G in right-arrow F out. H subscript c right-arrow J subscript M. J subscript M all with a slash through it right-arrow H subscript c all with a slash through it.

Below that is the Treasurer row with one spot. In the spot is F slash H. Below that is the Councillor row marked with two spots. To the right of the Councillor spot is K with a slash through it. To the right is an Out row marked with two spots. In the first Out spot is F slash G.

Below the diagram is a conditional logic rule. H subscript c right-arrow J subscript M. J subscript M all with a slash through it right-arrow H subscript c all with a slash through it.

options.passageText:
For an upcoming municipal election, members of a political party are nominating four individuals to run for three offices: one for mayor, one for treasurer, and two for councillor. There are six people being considered—Frost, Grant, Hu, Jensen, Kuno, and Llosa. The selection of nominees is subject to the following conditions:

If Frost is one of the nominees, Grant cannot be one of the nominees.

If Hu is a nominee for councillor, Jensen must be the nominee for mayor.

The nominee for treasurer must be either Frost or Hu.

Kuno cannot be a nominee for councillor.

question.content:
Which one of the following could be the selection of nominees, listed according to the offices for which they run?



[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This violates Rule 1 of the setup. **Frost** and **Grant** can’t both be nominees.
choices.content: mayor: Frost; treasurer: Hu; councillors: Grant and Jensen

choices.clue: This violates Rule 4 of the setup. **Kuno** cannot be a nominee for ***councillor***.
choices.content: mayor: Grant; treasurer: Hu; councillors: Kuno and Llosa

choices.clue: This violates Rule 3 of the setup. Only **Frost** or **Hu** can be nominated for ***treasurer***.
choices.content: mayor: Jensen; treasurer: Grant; councillors: Hu and Llosa

choices.clue: This violates Rule 2 of the setup. In this case, **Hu** is a nominee for ***councillor***, but **Jensen** isn’t the nominee for ***mayor***.
choices.content: mayor: Kuno; treasurer: Frost; councillors: Hu and Llosa

choices.clue: This doesn’t violate any of the setup rules.
choices.content: mayor: Kuno; treasurer: Hu; councillors: Frost and Llosa

question.content:
If Grant is a nominee for councillor, which one of the following must be true?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue:
This doesn’t have to be true. **Jensen** doesn’t have to be a nominee for ***councillor** in this situation, for example:

***mayor***: **Jensen**  
***treasurer***: **Hu**  
***councillor***: **Grant** and **Llosa**  
***out***: **Frost** and **Kuno**
choices.content: Jensen is the other nominee for councillor.

choices.clue:
This doesn’t have to be true. **Llosa** doesn’t have to be a nominee for ***councillor** in this situation, for example:

***mayor***: **Llosa**  
***treasurer***: **Hu**  
***councillor***: **Grant** and **Jensen**  
***out***: **Frost** and **Kuno**
choices.content: Llosa is the other nominee for councillor.

choices.clue:
This doesn’t have to be true. **Kuno** doesn’t have to be a nominee for ***mayor** in this situation, for example:

***mayor***: **Jensen**  
***treasurer***: **Hu**  
***councillor***: **Grant** and **Llosa**  
***out***: **Frost** and **Kuno**
choices.content: Kuno is the nominee for mayor.

choices.clue:
This doesn’t have to be true. **Frost** doesn’t have to be a nominee for ***treasurer** in this situation, for example:

***mayor***: **Jensen**  
***treasurer***: **Hu**  
***councillor***: **Grant** and **Llosa**  
***out***: **Frost** and **Kuno**
choices.content: Frost is the nominee for treasurer.

choices.clue: This must be true. We’re told that **Grant** is a nominee for ***councillor***. That means that **Frost** is Out (Rule 1), so **Hu** must be in the ***treasurer*** spot (Rule 3).
choices.content: Hu is the nominee for treasurer.

question.content:
Which one of the following pairs could be the two nominees for councillor?


[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This isn’t possible because it violates Rule 1. **Frost** and **Grant** can’t both be nominees.

This is possible:

***mayor***: **Kuno**  
***treasurer***: **Hu**  
***councillor***: **Frost** and **Jensen**  
***out***: **Grant** and **Llosa**

This isn’t possible. If **Hu** and **Grant** were in the ***councillor*** spots, then **Frost** would have to be ***treasurer*** (Rule 3) and that would break Rule 1 by making **Frost** and **Grant** nominees at the same time.
This isn’t possible because it violates Rule 2. If **Hu** is a nominee for ***councillor***, **Jensen** must be the nominee for ***mayor***.
This isn’t possible because it violates Rule 4. **Kuno** cannot be a nominee for ***councillor***.

question.content:
The selection of nominees and the offices for which they run is completely determined if which one of the following is NOT one of the nominees?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This doesn’t completely determine the selection. If **Frost** is out, the only thing we know is that **Hu** is nominated for ***treasurer*** (Rule 3).
This doesn’t completely determine the selection. If **Grant** is out, we can’t deduce much else.

This completely determines the selection. If **Hu** is out, then **Frost** is nominated for ***treasurer*** (Rule 3). That means that **Grant** must be out (Rule 1). The only place that **Kuno** can now go is in the ***mayor*** spot, since **Kuno** can’t be nominated for ***councillor*** (Rule 4). That leaves only **Jensen** and **Llosa** to occupy the remaining spots in the ***councillor*** group. That creates a completely determined scenario.

This is close, but it’s missing one deduction. If **Jensen** is out, then **Hu** can’t be nominated for ***councillor*** (Rule 2). That means that only **Llosa** and the **F/G** that isn’t Out can be nominated for **councillor** (they’re the only ones left, because **Kuno** can never be nominated for **councillor**). So, one of **F/G** is Out and the other of **F/G** is in the ***councillor*** group—that means that **Hu** must be ***treasurer***. That leaves **Kuno** to be ***mayor***. However, we don’t have enough information to know which of **Frost** and **Grant** is in and which is out.
This doesn’t completely determine the selection. If **Kuno** is out, we can’t deduce much else.

question.content:
If Kuno is one of the nominees, which one of the following CANNOT be a nominee for councillor?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue:
This is possible (so it’s not the answer, since we’re looking for someone who CANNOT be a nominee for ***councillor***), for example:

***mayor***: **Kuno**  
***treasurer***: **Hu**  
***councillor***: **Frost** and **Jensen**  
***out***: **Grant** and **Llosa**

This is possible (so it’s not the answer, since we’re looking for someone who CANNOT be a nominee for ***councillor***), for example:

***mayor***: **Kuno**  
***treasurer***: **Hu**  
***councillor***: **Grant** and **Jensen**  
***out***: **Frost** and **Llosa**

This is the answer, since **Hu** CANNOT be nominee for ***councillor*** in this situation. We know that **Kuno** can’t be ***treasurer*** (Rule 3) and that **Kuno** also can’t be ***councillor*** (Rule 4). So, if **Kuno** is one of the nominees, then it’s for ***mayor***. That triggers Rule 2’s contrapositive, which is that if **Jensen** *isn’t* ***mayor***, then **Hu** *isn’t* ***councillor***.

This is possible (so it’s not the answer, since we’re looking for someone who CANNOT be a nominee for ***councillor***), for example:

***mayor***: **Kuno**  
***treasurer***: **Hu**  
***councillor***: **Frost** and **Jensen**  
***out***: **Grant** and **Llosa**

This is possible (so it’s not the answer, since we’re looking for someone who CANNOT be a nominee for ***councillor***), for example:

***mayor***: **Kuno**  
***treasurer***: **Hu**  
***councillor***: **Frost** and **Llosa**  
***out***: **Grant** and **Jensen**

question.content:
Which one of the following, if substituted for the condition that Kuno cannot be a nominee for councillor, would have the same effect in determining the selection of nominees and the offices for which they run?


[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue:
This doesn’t have the same effect as Rule 4. Rule 4 still allows for someone other than **Jensen** or **Kuno** to be nominee for ***mayor***, for example:

***mayor***: **Llosa**  
***treasurer***: **Hu**  
***councillor***: **Grant** and **Jensen**  
***out***: **Frost** and **Kuno**
choices.content: The nominee for mayor must be either Jensen or Kuno.

choices.clue: This doesn’t have the same effect as Rule 4, although it is an inference that we could make. One problem with (B) is that if we substitute Rule 4 with (B), we can now include **Kuno** as one of the nominees for ***councillor***—and that’s directly in conflict with the original rule!
choices.content: The nominees for councillor must include Jensen or Llosa or both.

choices.clue:
This doesn’t have the same effect as Rule 4. With Rule 4, we could place **Frost** in the Out group and still place **Kuno** in one of the nominee groups, for example:

***mayor***: **Kuno**  
***treasurer***: **Hu**  
***councillor***: **Grant** and **Llosa**  
***out***: **Frost** and **Jensen**
choices.content: If Frost is not one of the nominees, Kuno cannot be one of the nominees.

choices.clue: This doesn’t have the same effect as Rule 4. It *is* an inference we can make. However, *replacing* Rule 4 with (D) means that **Kuno** *could* be a nominee for ***councillor** in some other situation (when **Hu** isn’t a nominee for ***councillor***). That’s a possibility that Rule 4 doesn’t allow for.
choices.content: If Hu is a nominee for councillor, Kuno cannot be one of the nominees.

choices.clue: This would have the same effect as Rule 4. We know that **Kuno** can’t be ***treasurer*** (Rule 3) and that **Kuno** also can’t be ***councillor*** (Rule 4). So, if **Kuno** is one of the nominees, then it’s for ***mayor***.
choices.content: If Kuno is one of the nominees, Kuno must be the nominee for mayor.

hints.content:
###What the setup tells us

Each of six companies offers either 5-year bonds only, 10-year bonds only, or both 5- and 10-year bonds. We’re given further information about the numbers: four companies offer 5-year bonds and four companies offer 10-year bonds. Since we’ll have eight spots and only six companies, that means that *two* of the companies will offer both. There’s no ordering task to work with, so this is a **grouping setup**. A basic diagram could start out like this:

[[☃ image 1]]

###What do the rules tell us?

* **Rule 1:** **HCN** cannot offer any type of bond that **Lorilou** does. We can show this using a rectangle with a line through it.

* **Rule 2:** If **VELSOR** offers ***5-year*** bonds, then **SamsonGonzales** must offer both types of bonds. This is a conditional logic rule, which means it’s usually a good idea to write down the logical equivalent as well: if **SamsonGonzales** *doesn’t* offer both bonds (in other words, doesn’t offer ***5-year*** or ***10-year*** bonds), then **VELSOR** *doesn’t* offer ***5-year*** bonds (in other words **VELSOR** would have to offer ***10-year*** bonds). 

* **Rule 3:** If **Lorilou** offers ***10-year*** bonds, then **RST** must also do so. This is another conditional logic rule. The logically equivalent rule would be: if **RST** *doesn’t* offer ***10-year*** bonds (in other words, offers ***5-year*** only), then **Lorilou** *doesn’t* offer ***10-year*** bonds (and must offer only ***5-year*** bonds):

[[☃ image 2]]

###What can we deduce?

* In many setups, the numbers line up well (6 horses and 6 spots, for example). That’s not the case in this setup, so it’s a good idea to pay attention to the numbers.
* Since *two* companies offer both types of bonds, that means that in each row, two of the companies listed will offer *only* that type of bond, and the other two companies listed will be the companies that offer both. This may sound obvious, but it’s worth paying attention to.
* Additionally, we can rule out **HCN** and **Lorilou** as the companies that offer both bonds, since neither of them can offer the same kind as the other. Let’s note an **=1** next to each of their initials in our list of elements.
* Moreover, we can actually reserve a spot in each group for **H/L**, given that one has to offer only one type of bond and the other company has to offer only the other type of bond.
* That leaves one more single-bond company in each group and two both-bond companies:

[[☃ image 3]]

That’s about all we can do for now, but we should find that taking a moment to analyze the numbers breakdown should prove very helpful in the questions!

options.passageText:
Six corporations—Goh Industrials, HCN, Lorilou, RST, SamsonGonzales, and VELSOR—each offer either or both of exactly two types of bonds—5-year and 10-year bonds—to finance their operations. Exactly four of the corporations offer 5-year bonds and exactly four offer 10-year bonds. Two of them offer both. No other types of bonds are offered. The bond offerings are subject to the following regulations:

HCN cannot offer any type of bond that Lorilou does.

If VELSOR offers 5-year bonds, then SamsonGonzales must offer both types of bonds.

If Lorilou offers 10-year bonds, then RST must also do so.

question.content:
Which one of the following could be an accurate matching of the types of bonds to the corporations that offer them?


[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This violates Rule 3 of the setup. In this case **Lorilou** offers ***10-year*** but **RST** doesn’t.

5-year bonds:  Goh Industrials, HCN, RST, SamsonGonzales  
10-year bonds:  Goh Industrials, Lorilou, SamsonGonzales, VELSOR

choices.clue: This doesn’t violate any of the setup rules.

10-year bonds:  Goh Industrials, HCN, SamsonGonzales, VELSOR

choices.clue: This violates Rule 2 of the setup. In this case, **VELSOR** offers ***5-year*** but **SamsonGonzales** doesn’t offer both.
choices.content:

That means that **HCN** offers ***5-year*** bonds and not ***10-year*** bonds (Rule 1). We can deduce from Rule 3 that **RST** must offer ***10-year*** bonds. The fourth company to offer ***10-year*** bonds, then, is either **SamsonGonzalez** or **Goh**.

Since we know that neither **Lorilou** nor **VELSOR** offers ***5-year*** bonds, and we deduced that **HCN* does, that leaves 3 open spots in the ***5-year*** group. Those spots can only be taken by **RST**, **Goh**, and **SamsonGonzalez**, since those are the only three companies left.

That means that **RST** must offer both types of bonds:

***10-year bonds***: **LVR G/S**

***10-year bonds***: **__LV__RG**  

In other words, if **SamsonGonzales** and **VELSOR** offer only bonds of a different type from one another, then that means that **VELSOR** offers the ***10-year*** bond and **SamsonGonzales** offers the ***5-year*** bond (Rule 2—if **VELSOR** offered only the ***5-year*** bond, then **SamsonGonzales** would have to offer both, which doesn’t conform to this question’s new condition). We already know that **HCN** and **Lorilou** must offer only one type of bond or the other, and opposite from each other. That means that **RST** and **Goh** are the two companies that offer *both* types of bonds.

[[☃ radio 1]]

This is possible:

***5-year bonds***: **__HG__SV**

This violates our setup rules, though! **Lorilou** can’t offer ***5-year*** bonds since **HCN** does (according to (D)), so there would be nowhere for **Lorilou** to go.
This isn’t possible, because it violates Rule 2. If **VELSOR** offers ***5-year***,  then **SamsonGonales** would have to offer both.

options.alt:
Two scenarios. Each is a grouping diagram that consists of two rows of four spots each. The top row is labeled 5-year and the bottom row is labeled 10-year. 

Scenario 1. The top row from left to right is G. L. Blank. Blank. To the right of the 5-year row is H with a slash through it. The 10-year row from left to right is H. R. S. V. To the right of the 10-year row is G with a slash through it and L with a slash through it.

question.content:
If Goh Industrials offers only one type of bond and HCN offers only the other type of bond, then which one of the following must be true?


[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue:
This doesn’t have to be true. **Goh** could offer ***5-year*** bonds only:

***5-year bonds***: **L__G__SV**  
***10-year bonds***: **HRSV**

This doesn’t have to be true. **RST** could offer ***10-year*** bonds only:

***5-year bonds***: **LGSV**  
***10-year bonds***: **H__R__SV**

This must be true. There are two scenarios possible here; either **Goh** offers ***5-year*** bonds only, or **Goh** offers ***10-year*** bonds only.

**Scenario 1:** **Goh** offers ***5-year*** bonds only.

* In this case, **HCN** offers ***10-year*** bonds only (according to the question’s new condition).
* **Lorilou** must offer ***5-year*** bonds only (Rule 1).
* The remaining three companies must occupy the remaining three spots in the ***10-year*** group: **RST**, **SamsonGonzales**, and **VELSOR**.

**Scenario 2:** **Goh** offers ***10-year*** bonds only.

* In this case, **HCN** offers ***5-year*** bonds only (according to the question’s new condition).
* **Lorilou** must offer ***10-year*** bonds only (Rule 1).
* This triggers Rule 3, and we can deduce that **RST** must also offer ***10-year*** bonds.

So, in both cases, **RST** offers ***10-year*** bonds.

This doesn’t have to be true. **VELSOR** could offer ***10-year*** bonds only:

***5-year bonds***: **LGRS**  
***10-year bonds***: **HRS__V__**

This doesn’t have to be true. **VELSOR** could offer ***5-year*** bonds only:

***5-year bonds***: **HRS__V__**  
***10-year bonds***: **LGRS**
